title: Direct & Manage Project Work
description: Learn how to execute the project management plan by directing and managing project work to create deliverables.
objectives: Understand Direct & Manage as the EXECUTION process that creates deliverables
Distinguish between planning (creating the plan) and executing (following the plan)
Recognize that execution generates work performance DATA (raw observations)
Identify when to deviate from plan (approved changes) vs when to follow plan strictly
Understand the PM's role in execution: Lead team, manage resources, implement approved changes, collect data
Apply execution principles to restaurant construction and operations

screens.headline: PM Plan approved! Construction starts. Javier (contractor): 'Electrical panel location conflicts with kitchen layout—can I move it 10 feet?' Alex must decide.
screens.body: Execution isn't just 'do what the plan says.' It's leading the team to create deliverables while managing changes, coordinating resources, and collecting performance data.

dialogue.text: Execution is where planning meets reality. Javier's question is typical: Plans are based on assumptions, but reality differs. Alex must decide: Is this a minor adjustment within scope, or a scope change requiring approval?

screens.learningHook: How do you execute a plan while handling real-world deviations? When can you adjust vs when do you need formal approval?

screens.title: Execution Decision Challenge
screens.instructions: Alex is executing the Riverside Plaza plan. Make decisions about changes, resources, and data collection.

scenarios.title: Stage 1: Can Alex Approve These Changes?
description: During execution, team members request changes. Which can Alex approve directly vs which need formal change control?
Rule: If change affects BASELINES (scope, schedule, cost), it needs CCB approval. If within approved baseline, PM can approve.

questions.question: Which changes can Alex approve DIRECTLY without CCB? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Javier wants to move electrical panel 10 feet (same room, no cost/schedule impact, meets code)
Maya wants to swap two menu items (both already in approved scope, same cost)
Carlos wants to add outdoor patio seating (new scope, +$40K, +4 weeks)
Javier discovers electrical upgrade needed (+$15K, +2 weeks)
Alex reassigns Devon from social media to email marketing (both tasks in plan, same budget)
Maya wants wood-fired oven painted copper instead of stainless (same cost, same timeline, aesthetic preference)

feedback.correct: Perfect! You identified PM-approval changes (a,b,e,f): minor adjustments within scope/budget. Changes c,d affect baselines (scope, schedule, cost) and need CCB approval.
feedback.incorrect: Review: PM can approve changes WITHIN baselines (electrical panel location within same room, menu swaps within approved scope). Changes affecting baselines (new scope like patio, cost overruns, schedule delays) need CCB approval.

scenarios.title: Stage 2: Work Performance Data Collection
description: Execution generates work performance DATA (raw observations). Alex must collect this data for monitoring and control.
Question: Which are examples of work performance DATA?

questions.question: Select all that are work performance DATA (raw observations from execution):

options.text: Kitchen construction is 60% complete (observation)
Kitchen is 10% behind schedule (analysis comparing to baseline)
Spent $350K on equipment (observation)
Equipment costs $50K over budget (analysis comparing to baseline)
Javier's team completed electrical rough-in on Tuesday (observation)
Electrical work is ahead of schedule (analysis)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Work performance DATA = raw observations (60% complete, $350K spent, work finished Tuesday). Options b,d,f are work performance INFORMATION (analysis comparing to baselines).
feedback.incorrect: DATA = raw observations from execution (% complete, costs spent, dates finished). INFORMATION = analysis comparing data to baselines (behind schedule, over budget). Execution generates DATA. Monitoring analyzes it into INFORMATION.

scenarios.title: Stage 3: PM's Role During Execution
description: What's Alex's role during execution? What should Alex focus on?

questions.question: Javier (contractor) is 3 days behind on electrical work. What should Alex do FIRST?

options.text: Tell Javier exactly how to do his job faster.
Collect work performance data (how many days behind? why? impact on critical path?), then analyze in monitoring process to determine if corrective action needed.
Immediately submit change request to extend deadline.
Do nothing—trust Javier to catch up on his own.

feedback.correct: Perfect! During execution, PM collects data (3 days behind, reason, impact). Analysis happens in monitoring process. Then decide if corrective action needed. Separate execution from monitoring/control.
feedback.incorrect: Execution focuses on DOING work and COLLECTING data. Analysis (is this a problem? do we need corrective action?) happens in monitoring process. Don't confuse execution (collect data) with control (analyze and act).

blocks.title: What Is Direct & Manage Project Work?

content.definition: Direct and Manage Project Work is the process of leading and performing the work defined in the PM Plan and implementing approved changes to achieve project objectives.
keyActivities: Create deliverables (build restaurant, hire staff, train team)
Implement approved changes (if CCB approved chef's table, add it now)
Manage resources (assign Javier to electrical, Maya to menu development)
Collect work performance data (% complete, costs spent, dates finished)

planning.activities: Define scope, schedule, budget, identify risks
planning.question: WHAT will we do and HOW?

execution.activities: Build deliverables, lead team, manage resources, collect data
execution.question: Actually DOING the work

content.integration: Execution implements what planning designed. If execution reveals plan gaps, update plan (progressive elaboration).

content.definition: Work performance data is the raw observations and measurements collected during execution.
examples: Kitchen construction 60% complete (not analyzed against baseline yet)
Spent $350K on equipment (raw cost, not compared to budget yet)
Hired 8 staff members (count, not compared to plan yet)
Oven delivery delayed by 5 days (observation, not analyzed for impact yet)
content.vs_information: DATA = raw observations (from execution). INFORMATION = analysis comparing to baselines (from monitoring). Execution generates data. Monitoring analyzes it.
content.why_matters: PM collects data during execution. Can't analyze performance without data. Data feeds monitoring process.

content.rule: PM can approve changes WITHIN baselines. Changes affecting baselines need CCB approval.

pm_can_approve: Move electrical panel 10 feet within same room (no scope/cost/schedule impact)
Swap menu items (both in scope, same cost)
Reassign team member between tasks (both tasks in plan)
Change meeting time (administrative, no baseline impact)
ccb_approval_needed: Replace wood-fired oven with gas oven (scope baseline change)

content.why: Baselines are frozen for performance measurement. Changes affecting them need governance (CCB approval). PM has authority for within-baseline adjustments.

content.misconception: Carlos thinks: 'Alex should be on-site 24/7 supervising every detail.'
content.reality: PM leads and coordinates, doesn't do all the work.
pm_does: Lead team (motivate, remove blockers, resolve conflicts)
Coordinate resources (ensure Javier has electrical supplies when needed)
Implement approved changes (add chef's table if CCB approved)
Collect performance data (% complete, costs, issues)
Facilitate collaboration (bring Maya, Marco, Carlos together)
Manage stakeholders (update Elena, communicate with mall developer)
content.analogy: Orchestra conductor doesn't play every instrument—conducts the musicians. PM leads specialists to create deliverables.

90-100.text: Excellent execution thinking! You understand the PM's role: lead the team, implement the plan, collect data, approve within-baseline changes, escalate baseline changes to CCB.

70-89.text: Good understanding of execution, but review when PM can approve vs when CCB approval is needed. Baseline changes = CCB. Within-baseline = PM.

below-70.text: Review the execution process. PM leads work (doesn't do all work), collects data (doesn't analyze yet—that's monitoring), approves within-baseline changes (escalates baseline changes to CCB).

screens.title: Software Project Execution
screens.context: You're executing software development. Development team is coding features per plan. QA team is testing. You're collecting performance data.

questions.question: Which are work performance DATA (not analysis)? Select all:

options.text: Completed 8 features (observation)
2 features behind schedule (analysis)
Found 15 bugs in testing (observation)
Bug rate is higher than acceptable (analysis)
Sprint 3 finished Friday (observation)

feedback.correct: Perfect! DATA = observations (8 features, 15 bugs, Sprint 3 Friday). INFORMATION = analysis (behind schedule, higher than acceptable).
feedback.incorrect: Remember: DATA = raw observations from execution (counts, dates, measurements). INFORMATION = analysis comparing to baselines. Execution generates data.

questions.question: Lead developer wants to refactor code structure (same functionality, better architecture, same timeline/cost). Can you approve?

options.text: No—all changes need CCB approval.
Yes—within scope baseline (same functionality), same schedule, same cost. PM can approve.
Ask the team to vote.
Wait until execution finishes, then decide.

feedback.correct: Excellent! Refactoring doesn't change scope (same features), schedule, or cost. PM can approve within-baseline technical decisions.
feedback.incorrect: PM can approve changes within baselines. Refactoring (same features, timeline, cost) doesn't affect baselines. Only baseline changes need CCB approval.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: Direct and Manage Project Work is the execution process where the PM leads the team to create deliverables, implements approved changes, manages resources, and collects work performance data.
takeaways: Execution = Implementing the PM Plan to create deliverables (building the restaurant, hiring staff)
PM leads work, doesn't do all work (conductor, not musician)
Execution generates work performance DATA (raw observations: % complete, costs spent, dates)
PM can approve within-baseline changes (electrical panel location, menu swaps)
Baseline changes need CCB approval (new scope, cost overruns, schedule delays)
PM's role: Lead team, coordinate resources, implement changes, collect data, manage stakeholders
Execution is separate from monitoring (execution = do work and collect data; monitoring = analyze data and control)

characterClosing.text: I thought Alex should supervise every detail 24/7. But Dr. Foster explained: Alex leads specialists (Javier does electrical, Maya does menu, Morgan does marketing). Alex coordinates them, removes blockers, collects performance data, ensures they have what they need. That's leadership, not micromanagement.

nextLesson.title: Managing Project Knowledge
nextLesson.teaser: Execution generates valuable knowledge—but only if you capture it! Learn how to manage project knowledge so lessons learned from Riverside Plaza inform future projects.
